article:
{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of the Nile |partof=the French
Revolutionary Wars |image= |caption=Detail from "The Destruction ofL'Orientat
the Battle of the Nile" George Arnald, 1827, National Maritime Museum, in
Greenwich, London, England |date=1â3 August 1798 |place=Aboukir Bay, Egypt,
Ottoman Empire |result=Decisive British victory |combatant1= |combatant2=
|commander1= Rear-Admiral, Sir Horatio Nelson |commander2= FranÃ§ois-Paul Brueys
d'Aigalliers |strength1=13 ships of the line, 1 fourth rate and one sloop
|strength2=13 ships of the line, 4 frigates |casualties1=218 killed 677
wounded |casualties2=2,000â5,000 casualties 3,000â3,900 captured 2 ships
of the line destroyed 9 ships of the line captured 2 frigates destroyed }}




The 'Battle of the Nile' (also known as the 'Battle of Aboukir Bay', in French
as the 'Bataille d'Aboukir' or in Egyptian Arabic as ÙØ¹Ø±ÙØ© Ø£Ø¨Ù ÙÙØ± Ø§ÙØ¨Ø­Ø±ÙØ©) was
a major naval battle fought between British Royal Navy and the Navy of the
French Republic at Aboukir Bay on the Mediterranean Sea coast off Egypt (then a
suzerainty of the Ottoman Empire), from 1â3 August 1798. The battle was the
climax of a naval campaign that had ranged across the Mediterranean during the
previous three months, as a large French convoy sailed from the naval base at
Toulon to Alexandria, main seaport (and former Greek/Hellenistic, Egyptian
capital under the ancient Ptolemies) carrying an expeditionary army under future
French First Consul and General Napoleon Bonaparte. The French were defeated by
the British forces led by Rear-Admiral Sir Horatio Nelson.

Bonaparte had sought to invade Egypt as the first step in a campaign against the
growing British economic and political colonies in India. In the Seven Years War
of 1756-1763, Britain had reduced the French colonies of India. As Bonaparte's
fleet crossed the Mediterranean Sea, it was pursued by a British force under
Nelson, sent from the British fleet in the Tagus, to establish the purpose of
the French expedition and defeat it.

For more than two months, Nelson chased the French, on several occasions only
missing them by a matter of hours. Bonaparte, aware of Nelson's pursuit,
enforced absolute secrecy about his destination and was able to capture Malta
and then land in Egypt without interception by the British naval forces.

With the French Republic's army ashore in Egypt, engaged in several battles
versus the local emir's Muslim, Egyptian/Ottoman forces and moving up the coast
into Palestine and Syria, the French fleet anchored in Aboukir Bay, a station
off the coast and north-east of Alexandria, in a formation that its commander,
Vice-Admiral FranÃ§ois-Paul Brueys D'Aigalliers, believed established a
formidable defensive position. When the British fleet arrived off Egypt on 1
August and discovered Brueys's dispositions, Admiral Nelson ordered an immediate
attack, and his ships advanced on the French line. As they approached, they
split into two divisions, one of which cut across the head of the line and
passed between the anchored French and the shore while the other engaged the
seaward side of the French fleet. Trapped in a crossfire, the leading French
warships were battered into surrender during a fierce three-hour battle, while
the centre was able to successfully repel the initial British attack. As British
reinforcements arrived, the centre came under renewed assault, and at 22:00
hours, the French flagship "[[French ship Orient (1791)|L'Orient]]" exploded.
With Admiral Brueys dead and his van and centre defeated, the rear division of
the French fleet attempted to break out of the bay, but ultimately only two
ships of the line and two frigates escaped, from a total of 17 ships engaged.

The battle reversed the strategic situation between the two nations' forces in
the Mediterranean, and entrenched the Royal Navy in a dominant position which
it would retain for the rest of the war. It also encouraged other European
countries to finally turn against France (shifting forces and changing sides
were a constant factor in 18th-century politics and wars), and was a factor in
the later outbreak of the War of the Second Coalition phase of the continuing
French Revolutionary Wars and the following Napoleonic Wars, which 21st-
century historians have dubbed the "Second Hundred Years War", that period of
almost constant conflict between the rivalries of Great Britain and France and
their changing allies and coalitions from 1714 to the Treaty and Congress of
Vienna in 1815.

Bonaparte's army was trapped in Egypt and Palestine, and the Royal Navy's
dominance of the Egyptian/Palestinian/Syrian coast contributed significantly to
his defeat at the Siege of the city of Acre in northern Palestine in 1799, which
preceded Bonaparte's return to Europe. Nelson, who had been wounded in the
battle, was proclaimed a hero across Europe and was subsequently made Baron
Nelson. His captains were also highly praised, and would go on to form the
nucleus of the legendary Nelsonic Band of Brothers. The battle has remained
prominent in the popular consciousness, with perhaps the best-known
representation being Felicia Hemans's 1826 poem [[Casabianca
(poem)|Casabianca]].
categories: Naval battles of the French Revolutionary Wars|Nile
